awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: An Optimization Framework for Designing Derived Attributes with Humans-in-the-loop
awd_abstract_narration:
Attribute design is one of the most challenging aspects of the Big Data Science pipeline, where raw attributes need to be transformed into easily-interpretable attributes that can aid data scientists in ad-hoc data exploration and building predictive models. Unfortunately, current automated techniques for attribute design do not offer adequate interpretability to the end user, and attribute designed by human data scientists is painstakingly slow and heavily reliant on domain expertise. This project will develop a novel and transformative approach to enable an ensemble of amateur human workers to be involved in the computational loop for attribute design. It will benefit various domains that require effective applications of Big Data Science. In addition, the project will improve the economic well-being of the country by involving amateur workers and fostering systematic development of a data science workforce. On the educational front, the project will have significant education and outreach activities that span K-12 as well as graduate Data Science education. 

The research involves developing a suite of algorithms and techniques for understanding the opportunities and challenges of involving an ensemble of human workers in attribute design, which is inspired by ensemble methods in Machine Learning. The main focus is on iterative methods to guide amateur human workers even with limited domain expertise to suggest new attributes for data exploration and predictive modeling. The research makes fundamental advancements to engineering by integrating theoretically-proven attribute design algorithms with application-specific details of real-world data science tasks. A prototype will be rigorously evaluated involving datasets from several application domains and human workers. The outcomes of this research will spur significant research in next generation human-in-the-loop computing, as well as impact data exploration over huge, high dimensional and unfathomable datasets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Attribute design plays a critical role in the Big Data Science pipeline, as raw attributes must be transformed into derived attributes that are interpretable and valuable for several downstream tasks. These tasks can include enabling k-nearest neighbor (kNN) queries, aggregate queries, or building predictive models. However, the current methods for designing attributes are labor-intensive, slow, and heavily reliant on domain expertise. While fully automated techniques exist for specific tasks, they often fail to provide the necessary explainability and flexibility that human analysts require for broader, ad-hoc data exploration. As data science continues to expand, the need for more efficient, scalable, and human-centered solutions to attribute design has become increasingly apparent. This project aims to address these challenges by introducing a novel approach to scaling the data science pipeline through the integration of human workers into the attribute design process. The intuition behind our project is that a combination of intelligences (e.g., human workers) will perform better than a single intelligence, which is the inspiration for ensemble methods in Machine Learning.

 

The project proposes three steps to “scale out” the data science pipeline by opening the doors to numerous human workers to assist in attribute design. First it proposes a mathematical framework that formally defines what constitutes an effective derived attribute. Then it focuses on designing human-friendly tools powered by scalable principled algorithms to assist workers in the intellectually demanding task of attribute design. Finally, the project addresses the challenge of designing algorithms for filtering and condensing the vast number of attributes generated by human workers.

 

The project has given rise to principled algorithms that are scalable and human-friendly tools to assist workers in the intellectually demanding task of attribute design.  It also has developed a mathematical framework that formalizes what constitutes an effective derived attribute. The framework designed a set of properties that attributes must possess to be deemed valuable in a data analysis context. These properties include relevance, surprise, diversity, and predictiveness, to name a few. For example, relevance can be defined in terms of how much an attribute contributes to the underlying data analysis task, while surprise refers to how unexpected or novel the attribute is compared to existing knowledge.  The project develops quantitative methods and scalable algorithms that can identify important attributes quickly and even in anytime fashion, using only pre-existing frequency distributions of individual attributes and retrieving records one at a time. Workers are then tasked with analyzing this subset and generating new attributes based on their expertise and intuition. The project also proposed principled solutions to condense a large set of human-generated attributes into a manageable set. The team was involved in conducting multifaceted evaluation during the project period that demonstrated generality, usability, and scalability of the proposed framework and the tool.

 

In conclusion, this project has successfully developed a scalable and human-in-the-loop framework for attribute design. By combining formal mathematical definitions of effective attributes, human-friendly tools, and principled algorithms, the project has significantly improved the attribute design process. The resulting framework ensures that derived attributes are not only effective and interpretable but also generalizable across different domains. This approach is a significant advancement in the field of data science and paves the way for future research where human intelligence and computational power work together to create more meaningful and effective attributes for data analysis.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Senjuti Basu Roy
